seo.title: Inside a Limoncello Factory
seo.description: How limoncello is made and what to look for in a quality bottle.

fallbackParagraph: What goes into real limoncello: lemons, alcohol, sugar, and time. Tours show the process and end with tastings — don’t drive afterwards.
intro: Touring a limoncello laboratory shows how sfusato Amalfitano lemons become the coast’s signature digestivo.
Learn the stages, taste small-batch bottles, and pick up tips on storing and transporting your favourite blend home.

sections.title: Sfusato Amalfitano lemons
body: Producers use thick-skinned sfusato Amalfitano lemons grown on terraced pergolas; their essential oils sit in the zest, not the juice.
Good tours start with a look at how the fruit is peeled by hand and why organic farming matters for a clean, aromatic infusion.

sections.title: From zest to infusion
body: Fresh zest steeps in neutral grain alcohol for a week or more until the liquid turns golden and fragrant.
After the infusion, the liquid is filtered and blended with simple syrup; batches rest to marry flavours before bottling.

sections.title: What tastings include
body: Guides usually walk you through the workspace, then pour small tastings of limoncello, crema di limone, or seasonal liqueurs.
Sip slowly, note texture and aroma, and skip driving afterwards—the samples are full strength even if they feel smooth.

sections.title: Buying and storing a bottle
body: Choose opaque glass or UV-protected bottles, and check labels for the producer’s address and production date.
Keep your bottle chilled once you open it at home; if you plan to travel with it, cushion it in clothing or ask the shop for protective packaging.

faqs.q: Can under-18 visitors join a tour?
a: Yes, minors can observe the process but legally cannot taste; some producers offer lemonades or granita as an alternative.

faqs.q: How can I bring limoncello home safely?
a: Pack bottles in checked luggage (carry-on limits prohibit liquids over 100 ml), cushion them well, and declare quantities if your country has strict alcohol import limits.
Unopened bottles stay fresh for up to a year; once opened, store them in the fridge or freezer and enjoy within a few months for peak aroma.
